subject: Art
title: Color Harmony
description: Why some color combinations feel pleasing and others feel jarring.

hook.text: Music has harmony ‚Äî notes that sound good together. Color works the same way. Some combinations feel effortlessly beautiful. Others hurt your eyes. The difference is structure.

buildup.text: Harmonious schemes follow the wheel: analogous (neighbors), complementary (opposites), triadic (triangle), split-complementary (Y-shape), tetradic (rectangle). Each creates a different type of visual agreement.

discovery.text: Harmony doesn't mean boring. It means the colors have a logical relationship. Within any scheme, you can still vary value, saturation, and proportion to create excitement.

twist.text: Disharmony is a deliberate tool too. Artists like Egon Schiele used clashing colors to create unease. If your subject matter is uncomfortable, a disharmonious palette supports the message.

climax.text: Before your next piece, pick a scheme from the color wheel first. Limit yourself to those colors. The constraint creates harmony automatically.

punchline.text: Harmony isn't random. It's geometric. The color wheel does the math for you.

quiz.question: What creates color harmony?
options: Colors that have a logical relationship on the color wheel
